Award.AwardTitle: EAGER: USBRCCR: HealthSense: Assessing and Protecting Privacy in Wireless Wearable Sensor-Generated Medical Data

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
Medical and body-worn sensors will enhance human health monitoring and diagnosis of critical ailments in the next decade. As the popularity of such devices increases, there will be an emergence of new and varied types of attacks targeting privacy intrusions. In all such cases, ensuring that user's physiological data is only accessed by authorized entities and confidentially transmitted to the remote medical experts is of critical importance. The project will first investigate the attack vectors resulting from wearable devices such as inference of private health information by analyzing the sensor data traffic transmitted over-the-air. To address such threats, the project will involve the design of a secure method of key establishment and communications between a body sensor and an external device, where signals are sent through the human tissue to eliminate eavesdropping. The project goals will be accomplished with collaboration from wireless security experts in Brazil, which will also lead to joint publications, student and faculty exchanges, and joint coursework development.

As part of the research undertaken in this project, the PIs will investigate how cross-layer and joint hardware-software fingerprinting techniques can be used to track a given user over time and space, and then identify with high probability, which types of medical sensing applications are active. This will be the first traffic analysis of health-specific body sensor traffic and building a comprehensive set of reference signatures for wearable sensors, which has so far not been addressed by classical techniques developed for Internet applications. The proposed tasks will also demonstrate a first-of-its-kind side-channel technique, using a non-radiating body channel, for secure key establishment, communications, and multi-factor authentication between body-worn sensors and the information-relaying device, such as a mobile phone. Underlying these methods is a technique called galvanic coupling, where weak electrical currents are modulated with the data signals, and then transmitted via highly conductive pathways of the human tissue. This shared secret can be both an encryption key as well as a randomized traffic shaping seed that eliminates RF sniffing, thereby mitigating the above types of privacy intrusions.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Wearable devices are increasingly popular, and as such becoming a security target of choice, especially when they access, store, and communicate sensitive information (including health-related). One of the main goals of this project is to investigate the attack vectors resulting from wearable devices such as inference of private information by analyzing the data traffic transmitted over-the-air. To address such threats, the project also involves the design of secure methods for key establishment and communications between a body sensor and an external device. One such approaches relies on communications through the human tissue to limit th e potential of eavesdropping. The method used for intra-body communication which is body-confined is Galvanic Coupling (GC). The project accomplished its goals in collaboration with wireless security experts in Brazil, leading to joint publications, and student and faculty exchanges.

The project activities included analysis of attack vector of wearable devices in particular devices with access to sensitive health information. In this initial phase, we considered ecosystems relying on standard wireless communication links such as Bluetooth and Wi-Fi. As such, we analyzed and demonstrated the potential of cross-layer side-channel RF fingerprinting. We conducted a security and privacy analysis of Apple Wireless Direct Link (AWDL) Wi-Fi which is deployed on more than one billion iOS and macOS devices and is used for device-to-device services such as Apple AirDrop, and by Apple Watch. We desinged and developed authentication mechanisms using intra-body communication to securely transmit and receive a cryptographic material (e.g., keys) through the human body channel. We evaluated and demonstrated good trade-offs in terms of energy consumption, body-confined secure communication, and safety of operation on the human body. We also designed, developped, and analyzed a system, called MATRIX, to protect the privacy of mobile device users from location inference and sensor side-channel attacks by malicious applications. MATRIX gives users control and visibility over location and sensor (e.g., Accelerometers and Gyroscopes) accesses by mobile apps. Its PrivoScope service allowing the to audit all location and sensor accesses by apps on the device and generates real-time notifications and graphs for visualizing these accesses; and a Synthetic Location service to enable users to provide obfuscated or synthetic location trajectories or sensor traces to apps they find useful, yet do not trust with their private information. 

  • Discovery of practical attack vectors on AWDL wearable devices that enable disclosure users private information such as identity (using low cost hardware e.g., $20 micro:bit), man-in-the-middle attacks, and denial of service. 
  • An analysis of intra-body communication (IBC) methods comparing RF technology, Ultrasound, Galvanic (GC), Capacitive, Magnetic resonance coupling and other emerging IBC technologies. A physical-layer testbed with a GC transmitter, receiver and phantom to evaluate the performance of our system in terms of security, BER, data rate, link distance, while providing  the building blocks for the development of adaptive secure IBC communication systems.
  • A Magnetic Resonance Coupling communication system design and implementation that enables data communication from implants to wearables as well as a quick alert system with guaranteed delivery time.
  • A framework for the Android mobile system, MATRIX, to protect the privacy of mobile device users from location inference and sensor side-channel attacks by malicious applications.
